page.title: 08THE SALISBURY PLAIN BUSTARDS
page.content: In the early 1850's the Great Bustard became extinct in Great Britain, and in the 1970's steps were taken to re- introduce them around the Salisbury Plain area where they used to breed. So the Bustard Trust was formed. The birds which are one of the most difficult species to breed in captivity, because they have no preen gland - which means that if they ever become water-logged could not fly - hence they were easy game for the hunters because of their tasty flesh. Since then a certain amount of success has been achieved, and a number of young Bustards have been reared. So after many years of patience and hard work by the trust, Great Bustards have been re-introduced in one part of Wiltshire and are soon to be re-introduced to this area of Salisbury Plain.
